title: Megyn Kelly, Contract Set to Expire Next Year, Is Primed for the Big Show - The New York Times
author: John Koblin
text: Barbara Walters is retired, Oprah Winfrey is running a network and Megyn Kelly sees an opening. â€œItâ€™s there for the taking right now,â€ she said in a recent interview. And what is there for the taking? What those famous hosts had accomplished: conducting the sort of interviews that could transfix a nation. â€œThose were the biggest spots to go for an interview if you had something you wanted to get off your chest, if you were in the middle of a scandal or a major news story and you wanted to do a     to get past it or to go on the record,â€ she said. She quickly added: â€œAnd Iâ€™m here!â€ Making the Oprah or Barbara Walters leap is a remarkably tricky business. Many have tried before, with daytime shows or   specials, only to run into a wall and return to a more comfortable corner of television. And the interview special is a relic from a time on television when what was broadcast on the Big Four networks was what mattered most. But on Tuesday, Ms. Kelly, the Fox News anchor and host of â€œThe Kelly File,â€ will take her first crack at a   special on Fox  â€”   the broadcast network, not the cable news station  â€”   with â€œMegyn Kelly Presents. â€ There is certainly one big hook to draw viewers: She will confront the likely Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, a man who over the last nine months has kept Ms. Kelly in the middle of a running news story by relentlessly attacking her. And though Mr. Trump represents the   get, she will also interview two actors (Michael Douglas and Laverne Cox) and a lawyer (Robert Shapiro) who is back in the news after the successful O. J. Simpson anthology â€œAmerican Crime Storyâ€ on FX. Mr. Trump aside, it is with those interviews that Ms. Kelly hopes to accomplish something new: prove that she can do much more than simply host a nightly news show. If all goes well, she will display range and versatility at a convenient time. Her contract with Fox News is set to expire in a little more than a year. â€œI would like to prove to myself that I have these other muscles,â€ she said, as she sat in her cramped office on Sixth Avenue. â€œIt doesnâ€™t all have to be   level of difficulty. It can be other kinds of questioning where you get more to somebodyâ€™s humanity and tell their story. â€ She said that one of her benchmarks for success was if viewers said: â€œI saw Megyn in a new light. â€ Her Fox News show, â€œThe Kelly File,â€ has been a hit for more than two years, but Ms. Kelly, who is 45, is in the middle of a big moment in her career. Since Mr. Trump began attacking her after the first Republican debate in August, Ms. Kelly has approached something close to genuine celebrity status. She was on the cover of Vanity Fair in February, she has made the rounds of the   circuit over the last three months. She also made her first appearance at the Met Gala in early May, the lavish Manhattan event that effectively serves as the yearâ€™s social register for the rich and famous. There is also a book in the works  â€”   she is handing in the manuscript to her editor at HarperCollins later this month and spent the last week writing the Trump section. It comes out the week after Election Day in November, and Tuesday will bring her the first   special. There are real questions whether the   â€œspecialâ€ can attract a meaningful audience and lift a career. Long gone are the days when Ms. Walters could attract an audience of about 50 million people, as her exclusive interview with Monica Lewinsky did in 1999. But even in a fragmented TV landscape, they can occasionally break through. Last year, Caitlyn Jennerâ€™s revelation that she was transgender in an interview with Diane Sawyer drew nearly 17 million viewers, which qualifies as a huge hit these days. Ms. Kelly was reluctant to discuss a ratings goal. The producer for â€œMegyn Kelly Presents,â€ the veteran TV newsman Bill Geddie, pointed out that Fox did not ordinarily run these type of news specials and that expectations should be managed accordingly. â€œMegyn said it right: Weâ€™re looking for a single here,â€ he said. The special can accomplish other goals for her instead. The news cycle has been relentlessly focused on politics and Ms. Kelly said she was more than happy to take a break from that. She is not a political junkie. â€œThatâ€™s not all I am,â€ she said â€œI love covering the news, but Iâ€™m not a political person, so I donâ€™t know that I get the jones out of immersing myself in politics all day, every day the way some others do. â€ She added, â€œYou look out at the news landscape, and there isnâ€™t the one perfect job that would service the soul. â€ If that turn of phrase makes her sound a little like Oprah, it is probably not by accident. She pointed to Ms. Winfrey and Charlie Rose to illustrate her broader goals. â€œOprahâ€™s a bit more spiritual and helps improve peopleâ€™s lives, which I also would like to do,â€ she said. â€œCharlie has a thing that I donâ€™t have. He will sit down with Brian Dennehy, whoâ€™s got an amazing show on Broadway, and talk to him about it. Heâ€™ll sit down with business executives like Tim Cook and talk to him about whatâ€™s happening in his life. â€ And if Ms. Kelly wants to be part Oprah, part Charlie Rose and also fill the Barbara Walters vacuum (â€œWho in their right mind would reject that?â€ she said of Ms. Walters) she got the right producer. Mr. Geddie produced more than 100 of Ms. Waltersâ€™s   specials. â€œMegyn Kelly Presentsâ€ will be quite a departure from her regular   show: Say goodbye to the talking heads and   cuts, and cue a gauzier look, with two comfortable chairs and a contemplative head nod. â€œItâ€™s nice to step outside of it every once in a while and try out the Louis Vuitton luggage,â€ she said. This is, of course, leads to the   question: What will happen when her contract expires next year? Whether or not the special is a success, she will have plenty of suitors lined up. And Fox News is keen to keep her. The special was the brainchild of the Fox News chairman, Roger Ailes, Ms. Kelly said. And she expressed loyalty to Mr. Ailes when asked about her future. â€œThe number of times heâ€™s had my back, given me opportunities, stuck his own neck out there to protect me, I feel very grateful to him. â€ She continued: â€œHaving said that, this is a fickle business, and you never say never. Every time Iâ€™ve been up for a contract negotiation Iâ€™ve been   to what possibilities exist. â€ Though the special may show how adept she is at interviewing a celebrity, much of the attention on Tuesday night will ultimately be on Mr. Trump, who made her his No. 1 media nemesis with his famous description of â€œblood coming out of her   â€¦     wherever. â€ Ms. Kelly said she planned to contact him for months but the attacks on her kept coming (Mr. Trump tweeted regularly about her, calling her â€œCrazy Megyn,â€ and he skipped the second Fox News debate in late January because of Ms. Kellyâ€™s involvement). She wanted him for this special, but it was not an easy assignment. Even Mr. Geddie, who has known Mr. Trump for 20 years, reached out and was given a flat no. It was not until April that Ms. Kelly reached out to Mr. Trump for the first time since the debate in August. She later met him alone at the Trump Tower to discuss the interview. Less than two weeks later, he was in. Though she concedes that Mr. Trump has made her â€œname better known,â€ she also refers to the last year as a dark one. There have been security concerns, and the stream of tweets from Mr. Trump and his supporters has been unpleasant. â€œThis is one of the things that I get into with Trump in the interview,â€ she said. â€œNot about me but about whether he realizes the power his words have on the lives of his targets. Not just Megyn Kelly. â€ In a campaign cycle in which the news media has been roundly criticized for kowtowing to Mr. Trump, Ms. Kelly has mostly been above it all. She even said on a March show: â€œIâ€™m the    show in all of cable news and I havenâ€™t had Trump on in seven months. It can be done without him too. â€ With the apparent rapprochement, is Ms. Kelly worried about the perception that she, too, is doing whatever needs to be done to get him for an interview? â€œListen, if I werenâ€™t a journalist, would I have called up Trump and said â€˜Letâ€™s meetâ€™? No, I would not,â€ she said. â€œBut itâ€™s because Iâ€™m a journalist he was attacking me to begin with. So, no, you cannot compare me trying to put an end to his   barrage so that I can cover him like a normal journalist with the    obsessive coverage we have seen of his candidacy. â€ Ms. Kelly expressed some frustration that she had been in the news for so long. Asked whether she thought Mr. Trumpâ€™s attacks would end after the special was broadcast, she took a long pause, and said, without a great deal of confidence: â€œI hope so. One never knows. â€

title: Teacher Suspended for Allowing Students to Hit Trump Pinata for Cinco de Mayo
author: Katherine Rodriguez
text: A high school Spanish teacher from Colorado has been suspended after she reportedly made a piÃ±ata with President Trumpâ€™s face on it and allowed her students to hit it. [Johnstown Milliken School District Superintendent Martin Foster said the incident took place at Roosevelt High School in Johnstown during the Spanish classâ€™s celebration of Cinco de Mayo, CBS Denver reported.  â€œThis was an incredibly disrespectful act that does not reflect the values of Roosevelt High School or the school district,â€ Foster said in a statement. The teacherâ€™s name has not yet been released. Photos and video of the incident circulated on Facebook and Snapchat, offending many parents. â€œHeâ€™s been defeated,â€ read one caption of a Snapchat photo showing two students holding up the   piÃ±ata with Trumpâ€™s face on it. One parent, Lesley Hollywood, posted the Snapchats to Facebook and shared her displeasure with the incident: â€œIt is disturbing that this would be happening in a school setting,â€ Hollywood told CBS Denver. â€œWhy divide people? Why do this? There are so many other ways we can address politics in schools. â€ Hollywood said that according to some of the students, the piÃ±ata also featured an image of Mexican President Enrique PeÃ±a Nieto. â€œI wouldnâ€™t of cared if it was Obamaâ€™s face on that piÃ±ata, or if it had been Hillary Clintonâ€™s face,â€ Hollywood added. â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter. This is not how we should be teaching our children politics in this country. â€ KDVR reported that the district will launch an investigation starting Monday.

title: Snap Shares Leap 44% in Debut as Investors Doubt Value Will Vanish - The New York Times
author: Michael J. de la Merced
text: Snapchat is a business built in large part on disappearing messages and adding animated dog ears and flower crowns to usersâ€™ selfies. As of Thursday, that business is worth about $34 billion  â€”   more than the market value of the   media company CBS, and about three times the size of another social media company, Twitter. Snapchat has made paper billionaires of its   founders five times over. In making its stock market debut in spectacular fashion  â€”   its shares rising 44 percent on their first day of trading  â€”   Snapchatâ€™s parent, Snap Inc. has blazed a trail for other technology darlings like Uber and Spotify that remain privately held. It elated Wall Street institutions eager for a prominent initial public offering when few had surfaced for months. The company has entranced investors despite a litany of red flags, like enormous losses that are expected to persist for years, a slowdown in its   user growth rates, and an ownership structure that gives Snapchatâ€™s founders control for decades to come. Then there are the shadows of onetime tech highfliers that have since crashed to earth. Twitter was valued at nearly $32 billion at the end of its first day of trading Wall Street now values it at roughly $11 billion and has called for the company to sell itself. An earlier force in social media, Myspace, sold itself to Rupert Murdochâ€™s News Corporation for $580 million in 2005 six years later, it was sold to Justin Timberlake and other investors for $35 million. Some analysts have already shown skepticism about the newest publicly traded tech giant. One, Brian Wieser of Pivotal Research Group, says the share price should be $10, far below the companyâ€™s offering price of $17, which itself was above the initial range predicted. Snap faces competition from larger companies and the challenge of a   user base, he said. Boosters of Snapâ€™s prospects argue instead that Snap has the potential to become less like Twitter and more like its biggest rival, the $395 billion Facebook. These supporters point to some of the companyâ€™s obvious strengths: the 158 million people on average who used Snapchat each day by the end of 2016 the roughly 18 times a day that those users opened the app on average the $404 million in sales that it collected last year, up from nothing three years ago. For now, investors appeared to focus on the positive. Snap raised $3. 4 billion in its market debut, the most by an American tech company since Facebookâ€™s initial offering in 2012, according to data from Renaissance Capital. It was the first significant tech stock sale since at least December. And the 44 percent pop in its stock price was the biggest enjoyed by a company of a   I. P. O. since Twitterâ€™s debut in 2013. More than 217 million shares traded on Thursday, as some investors bought and others cashed in, exceeding the number of shares Snap sold in the I. P. O. For investors in other   unicorns  â€”   a term for   valued at more than $1 billion  â€”   the immense success of Snapâ€™s deal highlights the appetite for a tech darling, even if the company still bleeds money. Count Uber, Spotify and Airbnb within that group. â€œThe sound youâ€™re hearing today after the Snap I. P. O. is the happy snapping of fingers of   unicorns and their investors,â€ said Kathleen Smith, a principal at Renaissance Capital. â€œIt looks like Snap has set the path to monetization. â€ In countless meetings during a   roadshow with investors, Snap executives sought to rebut some of the biggest concerns about the companyâ€™s prospects. Slowing growth toward the end of last year stemmed from problems with the serviceâ€™s Android app. Competition from Facebook, which openly copied some of Snapchatâ€™s signature features at Instagram, would do little to dent user enthusiasm. And the company would continue to press innovations, such as the branded lens filters that transform users into monsters, fairies or Taco Bell tacos, and that have become new forms of advertising beloved by brands. Potential new ideas include drones and   cameras. By Wednesday night, Snapâ€™s bankers had drawn up their list of the investors who would get the first shares, largely big mutual funds and some hedge funds, all with the aim of picking firms that are most likely to stick around for the long term. The I. P. O. minted wealth for others that invested when it was a younger company, including big venture capital firms like Benchmark Capital and a high school in the Bay Area. Unlike newly public companies that seek to celebrate their first day of trading on the stock markets, Snap kept its festivities largely confined to the New York Stock Exchange. The companyâ€™s top executives and board members gathered there for a   breakfast, where guests were presented with pins in the shape of Snapchatâ€™s ghost mascot. Evan Spiegel, 26, and Bobby Murphy, 28, Snapâ€™s founders, briefly addressed the crowd, uncharacteristically clad in suits and ties rather than their customary  . They also presented exchange officials with their version of the customary gift given by market debutants: one of the vending machines that sell the companyâ€™s Spectacles,   sunglasses that send   videos to the app. (The machine wonâ€™t be refilled once it sells out of Spectacles.) Then the founders walked through the floor of an exchange bedecked in the companyâ€™s signature yellow  â€”   the color splayed on electronic boards, wrapped around water bottles and leaping off some executivesâ€™ ties. One Snap employee had ducked into the HermÃ¨s store down the street to pick up a yellow tie days before just for the occasion. Mr. Spiegelâ€™s fiancÃ©e, the supermodel Miranda Kerr, enthusiastically documented the day on her own Snapchat Story and posed for selfies. Attendees on the floor could unlock a special filter that placed the companyâ€™s ghost mascot in their videos, holding virtual Snapchat balloons and ejecting a rainbow from its mouth. At 9:30 a. m. Mr. Spiegel and Mr. Murphy rang the Big Boardâ€™s opening bell and then briefly basked in the adulation. Snapâ€™s chief strategy officer, Imran Khan, escorted his family around the exchange and posed for pictures with fellow employees. But by the time Snapâ€™s shares opened for trading at $24 each  â€”   which was later in the morning  â€”   the companyâ€™s top executives had disappeared from the floor, heading to the nearby offices of one of the banks involved in the public offering, Goldman Sachs, to watch the opening. Then many staff members trekked to Snapâ€™s Midtown Manhattan offices to head back to work.

title: Clinton Campaign Chair Had Dinner With Top DOJ Official One Day After Hillaryâ€™s Benghazi Hearing
author: admin
text:
Zero Hedge October 26, 2016 
In the latest revelation sure to reignite accusations of collusion between the Clinton campaign and the DOJ, among the recent batch of hacked emails released by Wikileaks, we learn that the day after Hillary Clinton testified in front of the House Select Committee on Benghazi last October, John Podesta, Hillaryâ€™s campaign chairman met for dinner with a small group of well-connected friends, including Peter Kadzik , who is currently a top official at the US Justice Department serving as Assistant Attorney General for Legislative Affairs. 
Peter Kadzik, with lobbyist Tony Podesta, brother of John Podesta . 
The post-Benghazi dinner was attended by Podesta, Kadzik, superlobbyist Vincent Roberti and other well-placed Beltway fixtures. The first mention of personal contact between Podesta and Kadzik in the Wikileaks dump is in an Oct. 23, 2015 email sent out by Vincent Roberti, a lobbyist who is close to Podesta and his superlobbyist brother, Tony Podesta. In it, Roberti refers to a dinner reservation at Posto, a Washington D.C. restaurant. The dinner was set for 7:30 that evening, just one day after Clinton gave 11 hours of testimony to the Benghazi Committee . 
Podesta and Kadzik met several months later for dinner at Podestaâ€™s home, another email shows . Another email sent on May 5, 2015 , Kadzikâ€™s son asked Podesta for a job on the Clinton campaign. 
As the Daily Caller notes , the dinner arrangement â€œis just the latest example of an apparent conflict of interest between the Clinton campaign and the federal agency charged with investigating the former secretary of stateâ€™s email practices.â€ As one former U.S. Attorney tells told the DC, the exchanges are another example of the Clinton campaignâ€™s â€œcozy relationshipâ€ with the Obama Justice Department. 
The hacked emails confirm that Podesta and Kadzik were in frequent contact. In one email from January, Kadzik and Podesta, who were classmates at Georgetown Law School in the 1970s, discussed plans to celebrate Podestaâ€™s birthday. And in another sent last May, Kadzikâ€™s son emailed Podesta asking for a job on the Clinton campaign. A d v e r t i s e m e n t 
â€œThe political appointees in the Obama administration, especially in the Department of Justice, appear to be very partisan in nature and I donâ€™t think had clean hands when it comes to the investigation of the private email server,â€ says Matthew Whitaker, the executive director of the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust, a government watchdog group. 
â€œ Itâ€™s the kind of thing the American people are frustrated about is that the politically powerful have insider access and have these kind of relationships that ultimately appear to always break to the benefit of Hillary Clinton ,â€ he added, comparing the Podesta-Kadzik meetings to the revelation that Attorney General Loretta Lynch met in private with Bill Clinton at the airport in Phoenix days before the FBI and DOJ investigating Hillary Clinton. 
Kadzikâ€™s role at the DOJ, where he started in 2013, is particularly notable Kadzik, as helped spearhead the effort to nominate Lynch, who was heavily criticized for her secret meeting with the former president. 
A Long, Friendly History 
Podesta and Kadzik have a long history, one which has surprisingly gone mostly unnoticed during the ongoing Clinton email scandal. As DC helps summarize, Kadzik represented Podesta during the Monica Lewinsky investigation. And in the waning days of the Bill Clinton administration, Kadzik lobbied Podesta on behalf of Marc Rich, the fugitive who Bill Clinton controversially pardoned on his last day in office. 
That history is cited by Podesta in another email hacked from his Gmail account. In a Sept. 2008 email , which the Washington Free Beacon flagged last week, Podesta emailed an Obama campaign official to recommend Kadzik for a supportive role in the campaign. Podesta, who would later head up the Obama White House transition effort, wrote that Kadzik was a â€œfantastic lawyerâ€ who â€œ kept me out of jail.â€ 
As the DC Chuck Ross notes, it is unclear to which case Podesta was referring and whether he was joking about prison. But Podesta was caught in a sticky situation in both the Lewinsky affair and the Rich pardon scandal. As deputy chief of staff to Clinton in 1996, Podesta asked then-United Nations ambassador Bill Richardson to hire the 23-year-old Lewinsky . In April 1996, the White House transferred Lewinsky from her job as a White House intern to the Pentagon in order to keep her and Bill Clinton separate. But the Clinton team also wanted to keep Lewinsky happy so that she would not spill the beans about her sexual relationship with Clinton. 
Richardson later recounted in his autobiography that he offered Lewinsky the position but that she declined it. 
Podesta made false statements to a grand jury impaneled by Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr for the investigation. But he defended the falsehoods, saying later that he was merely relaying false information from Clinton that he did not know was inaccurate at the time. â€œHe did lie to me,â€ Podesta said about Clinton in a National Public Radio interview in 1998. Clinton was acquitted by the Senate in Feb. 1999 of perjury and obstruction of justice charges related to the Lewinsky probe. Kadzik, then a lawyer with the firm Dickstein Shapiro Morin & Oshinsky, represented Podesta through the fiasco. 
Podesta had been promoted to Clintonâ€™s chief of staff when he and Kadzik became embroiled in another scandal. 
Kadzik was then representing Marc Rich, a billionaire financier who was wanted by the U.S. government for evading a $48 million tax bill. The fugitive, who was also implicated in illegal trading activity with nations that sponsored terrorism, had been living in Switzerland for 17 years when he sought the pardon. To help Rich, Kadzik lobbied Podesta heavily in the weeks before Clinton left office on Jan. 20, 2001. A House Oversight Committee report released in May 2002 stated that â€œKadzik was recruited into Marc Richâ€™s lobbying campaign because he was a long-time friend of White House Chief of Staff John Podesta.â€ 
The report noted that Kadzik contacted Podesta at least seven times regarding Richâ€™s pardon. 
On top of the all-hands-on-deck lobbying effort, Richâ€™s ex-wife, Denise Rich, had doled out more than $1 million to the Clintons and other Democrats prior to the pardon. She gave $100,000 to Hillary Clintonâ€™s New York Senate campaign and another $450,000 to the Clinton presidential library. 
Kadzikâ€™s current role 
In his current role as head of the Office of Legislative Affairs, Kadzik handles inquiries from Congress on a variety of issues. In that role he was not in the direct chain of command on the Clinton investigation. The Justice Department and FBI have insisted that career investigators oversaw the investigation, which concluded in July with no charges filed against Clinton. 
But Kadzik worked on other Clinton email issues in his dealings with Congress. Last November, he denied a request from Republican lawmakers to appoint a special counsel to lead the investigation . 
In a Feb. 1, 2016 letter in response to Kadzik, Florida Rep. Ron DeSantis noted that Kadzik had explained â€œthat special counsel may be appointed at the discretion of the Attorney General when an investigation or prosecution by the Department of Justice would create a potential conflict of interest.â€ 
DeSantis, a Republican, suggested that Lynchâ€™s appointment by Bill Clinton in 1999 as U.S. Attorney in New York may be considered a conflict of interest. He also asserted that Obamaâ€™s political appointees â€” a list which includes Kadzik â€” â€œare being asked to impartially execute their respective duties as Department of Justice officials that may involve an investigation into the activities of the forerunner for the Democratic nomination for President of the United States. â€ 
It is unknown if Kadzik responded to DeSantisâ€™ questions. 
Kadzikâ€™s first involvement in the Clinton email brouhaha came in a Sept. 24, 2015 response letter to Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Chuck Grassley in which he declined to confirm or deny whether the DOJ was investigating Clinton. Last month, Politico reported that Kadzik angered Republican lawmakers when, in a classified briefing, he declined to say whether Clinton aides who received DOJ immunity were required to cooperate with congressional probes. 
Kadzik also testified at a House Oversight Committee hearing last month on the issue of classifications and redactions in the FBIâ€™s files of the Clinton email investigation. This article was posted: Wednesday, October 26, 2016 at 9:52 am Share this article

title: TV Series About â€™First Female MLB Pitcherâ€™ Canned After One, Low-Rated Season - Breitbart
author: Warner Todd Huston
text: After a stunted   order, the Fox baseball series â€œPitchâ€ has officially struck out. [The TV series telling the story of the fictional â€œfirst female pitcher in Major League Baseballâ€ has been canceled after a single, shortened and   season, Fox has announced.  Executive producer Kevin Falls revealed the networkâ€™s decision on his Twitter feed, thanking the â€œfaithful fansâ€ for â€œtrying so hardâ€ to save the show. Iâ€™m sorry to tell you that @PITCHonFOX will not be getting a second season. #Pitch,  â€”   Kevin Falls (@KevinFalls) May 2, 2017,  Falls heads up Left Coast Productions, and if â€œPitchâ€ was any indication, then the â€œleftâ€ part of that moniker is fitting. Within the first two minutes of the opening scene of the first episode, â€œPitchâ€ worked in both gay activist and TV host Ellen DeGeneres and former Secretary of State and failed Democrat candidate for president, Hillary Clinton. The first few episodes of the short order, single season also featured Fox Sports 1â€™s Katie Nolan, who portrayed herself as a TV sports analyst, the same Katie Nolan who took to Twitter to call popular Fox News personality Sean Hannity a â€œliteral fu**ing moron. â€ Some say that Fox hurt the series when it rushed the show to air months earlier than its original Spring of 2017 launch date. The network jumped the show into rotation, though, after ABC moved â€œScandalâ€ to accommodate star Kerry Washingtonâ€™s pregnancy. Fox thought it could capitalize on audiences looking for a series starring a strong female lead, but audiences didnâ€™t comply with the networkâ€™s hopes. Star Kylie Bunbury, who portrayed the titular â€œPitchâ€ character Ginny Baker, tweeted that her â€œheart is heavy. â€ My heart is heavy. ğŸ’” Pitch will not be returning. I donâ€™t have some eloquently thought out  â€¦     https:  .   â€”   Kylie Bunbury (@kyliebunbury) May 2, 2017,  The fictional baseball series had a lot of early buzz, but according to Variety, the show never connected with viewers and earned dismal ratings â€œaveraging a 0. 8    day Nielsen rating in the   demo and 3 million total viewers per episode. â€ In a piece published by MRCTV. org, Breitbart Sportsâ€™ Dylan Gwinn jabbed the idea that a woman could compete as a pitcher in the Major Leagues. The concept was wholly unbelievable, Gwinn said, because â€œthe fastest pitch ever thrown by a woman was 69 mph, a feat easily reached, and frequently surpassed, by most male high school pitchers. â€ Follow Warner Todd Huston on Twitter @warnerthuston or email the author at igcolonel@hotmail. com.

title: Seeking Best Fit, Womenâ€™s Final Four Returns to Friday-Sunday - The New York Times
author: JerÃ© Longman
text: DALLAS  â€”   The womenâ€™s Final Four is a showcase in search of a proper audience. In recent years, the N. C. A. A. has explored various options for rejuvenating its most popular womenâ€™s sporting event, seeking to counter indifferent attendance at this marquee championship. A study in 2013 offered several bold ideas, like holding the Womenâ€™s Final Four at the same site as the menâ€™s event, or even moving it to Europe, China, Russia or Qatar. Another, less radical, proposal was to return the Final Four to a   format, from  . The new schedule was adopted for this year, and so on Friday night, the national semifinals took place at American Airlines Center here, with South Carolina defeating Stanford,   in the first game before Mississippi State upset Connecticut,   in the second. Capacity crowds were expected for the two semifinals and the final, the N. C. A. A. said. With weekend games, fans do not have to miss a considerable part of the workweek to attend the Final Four, as they did when the championship game was played on a Tuesday night from 2003 to 2016. (The menâ€™s Final Four continues to have a   format.) Also, some believed the womenâ€™s final had begun to feel anticlimactic when it was played a night after the menâ€™s final. That seemed especially true last year, when Villanova defeated North Carolina on a   shot the day before UConn swamped Syracuse by 31 points. â€œThe reason we moved to   was based on a lot of surveys and people saying, from a fan experience, that having to take that whole additional week off when we played on Tuesday was difficult,â€ said Rick Nixon, the N. C. A. A.â€™s associate director of championships and a spokesman for the organization. â€œTo be in a   situation here in Dallas on Friday and Sunday, I think itâ€™s worked out. â€ In effect, the N. C. A. A. seems to have put a higher premium on a full arena than expanded television ratings. Fridayâ€™s semifinals were to be broadcast on ESPN2, competing with an N. B. A. doubleheader on ESPN featuring San   City and Golden  . Sundayâ€™s championship game will not have its accustomed   slot on ESPN, either. Instead, it will start at 6 p. m. Eastern time, ahead of the networkâ€™s opening night coverage of Major League Baseball, featuring the World Series champion Chicago Cubs at rival St. Louis. â€œWeâ€™re anxious to see where the ratings play out,â€ Nixon said. â€œIt might not be all bad. â€ ESPN said it would have preferred to retain the   format. Kara Lawson, a commentator, told The Hartford Courant that the move to ESPN2 of Fridayâ€™s semifinals, usually broadcast on ESPN, was a â€œbig bummer for exposure of the game. â€ Carol Stiff, vice president for womenâ€™s sports programming at ESPN, was more sanguine. An arena at capacity is â€œgood for the game,â€ she said, and in reference to the womenâ€™s final, she added, â€œI think we might pull in more numbers on a Sunday. â€ The final will be promoted as part of a â€œSuper Sunday,â€ Stiff said. â€œFrom the crowning of a champion to handing it over to the Cubs, itâ€™s a pretty big day. â€ Not everyone was pleased with the time slots for Fridayâ€™s semifinals. The tipoff for   Carolina was set for 7:30 p. m. while UConn was set to play Mississippi State at closer to 10 p. m. The Huskies draw the biggest ratings in womenâ€™s college basketball, but Coach Geno Auriemma said he was not happy that his team would have to wait around all day to play. â€œIâ€™ve said this in the past  â€”   TV and whatâ€™s going on in the actual arena donâ€™t go together,â€ he said on Thursday. He added: â€œWe have to figure out how to work together, make it work for the   because we always use that term, you know. Whatâ€™s best for the  ? Not playing at 10 at night. â€ Another underlying issue in womenâ€™s college basketball is the debate about whether the dominance of UConn  â€”   with its   winning streak entering Friday, and its four consecutive national championships  â€”   is good or bad for the development of the sport. On the face of it, it might seem absurd to claim that sustained excellence was somehow detrimental. While the womenâ€™s regionals had their lowest average attendance in 20 years, according to The Associated Press, with an average of 4, 719 fans at each game, UConn sold out both the regional semifinal and the final in Bridgeport, Conn. drawing announced crowds of 8, 978. In February, when UConn won its 100th consecutive game, against South Carolina, it drew the highest television rating of the season, to that point, on ESPN2 for any college game, menâ€™s or womenâ€™s. â€œI think theyâ€™re great for the game,â€ Stiff said of Auriemma and the Huskies. â€œEvery time theyâ€™re on, people are tuning in. They want to know, what is special about this team? Whatâ€™s in the sauce? Can he coach men? Whatâ€™s the magic in the potion? This was supposed to be his down year. â€

title: A Proposal for a Canadian National Bird Ruffles Feathers - The New York Times
author: Ian Austen
text: OTTAWA  â€”   With Canadaâ€™s 150th anniversary looming next year, a gap was noticed in the countryâ€™s roster of patriotic icons. It had a national anthem, a national tree, two national animals, two national sports  â€”   but no national bird. That would not do. The United States has the bald eagle, Mexico the golden eagle, France the rooster. Down in El Salvador they have the   motmot. But Canada, one of the worldâ€™s major bird habitats, had gone a century and a half without ever choosing an avian avatar. Why? The Department of Canadian Heritage, the official government keeper of symbols, could not explain it. Neither could ornithologists, nor the editor of Canadian Geographic magazine, Aaron Kylie. So the Royal Canadian Geographic Society, which publishes the magazine and perhaps saw a chance for some nice publicity, took up the   task of selecting one. And boy, did it ruffle feathers. To get the public involved, the society set up a website where Canadians could vote for their favorite bird  â€”   but it did not promise to heed the result. (Nobody wanted something like the â€œBoaty McBoatfaceâ€ online   debacle.) Instead, a panel of experts was given the final say. Prominent Canadian writers championed their favorites in the magazineâ€™s pages, and the contest became a popular topic on (of course) Twitter under the hashtag #CanadaBird. The society even staged a public debate in September, with naturalists and Canadaâ€™s poet laureate, George Elliott Clarke, each backing a species. And then came the big reveal. The proposed Canadian national bird would be   â€¦     the gray jay. The what? Itâ€™s a fluffy songbird found in all 13 of Canadaâ€™s provinces and territories, which is a plus. But it tends to stick to the deep northern woods, and isnâ€™t often seen as far south as the strip of land along the American border where most Canadians live. To them, the gray jay is a stranger. David Bird, a professor emeritus of wildlife biology and an ornithologist at McGill University in Montreal, was the birdâ€™s booster in the debate. In an interview, Professor Bird gave a long list of reasons. For example, he said that instead of migrating, the gray jay stays in Canada and nests through the winter, feeding on frozen food that it stashed away in the fall under the loose bark of spruce trees. Mating pairs are monogamous, he said, unlike many other species. And gray jays like people when they meet them, alighting on their clothing or hands in the hope of a snack. â€œYouâ€™ve got loyal, youâ€™ve got friendly, youâ€™ve got smart, youâ€™ve got hearty: Thatâ€™s what Canadians think we are,â€ Professor Bird said. What you havenâ€™t got is huge popularity. When about 50, 000 people voted in the magazineâ€™s online poll, the gray jay finished third, behind the loon, which adorns Canadaâ€™s   coin, and the snowy owl. â€œI know a lot of Canadians didnâ€™t know what the gray jay was, and were asking: â€˜Do I see it in my feeder? â€™â€ Professor Bird said. â€œAnd there are still people angry because they felt the popular vote was not honored. â€ Mr. Kylie, the editor of Canadian Geographic, said that the loon and snowy owl were excluded from final consideration because they were already used as symbols by the provinces of Ontario and Quebec. He said the relative unfamiliarity of the gray jay, also known as the whiskey jack, weighed on the plus side, not the minus. â€œWe have an animal symbol, which is the beaver,â€ he said by way of analogy. â€œI would say that most Canadians donâ€™t see a beaver in a given year. The fact that some Canadians donâ€™t know this bird, I think, is all the more reason to have it proclaimed the national bird. â€ Then you have the spelling of the birdâ€™s names. Following the usual Canadian style, it ought to be called the grey jay, with an e, or the whisky jack, without one. The â€œgrayâ€ and â€œwhiskeyâ€ spellings are seen (and resented) as Americanisms. The issue particularly vexes Dan Strickland, who began researching the bird as a graduate student at the UniversitÃ© de MontrÃ©al in late 1960s and continues to do so even after retiring as chief naturalist at Algonquin Provincial Park in Ontario. The spellings, he said, come from the American Ornithologistsâ€™ Union, which took it upon itself to determine official names for all the birds in North America. The union gave the species the Latin name Perisoreus canadensis, and at first, from 1886 to 1910, referred to it in English as the Canada jay. The union dropped all English bird names in 1910, but brought them back later, and the current ones stem from a sweeping revision of its naming system in 1957. Mr. Strickland, whose license plate reads GRAY JAY, said that if the government did adopt the bird as a symbol, it ought to legislate a Canadian name for it. â€œThe bird is obviously a viable, valid contender to be the national bird,â€ Mr. Strickland said. â€œBut it is entirely inappropriate for the Canadian national bird to have a name imposed by a   foreign body. The A. O. U. can fall into line for once, or do whatever they want. But they do not get to name our national symbols. â€ However you spell it, the magazineâ€™s proposal has met with a cool reception from officialdom. â€œAt this time, the government of Canada is not actively considering proposals to adopt a bird as a national symbol,â€   Herbert, the press secretary for MÃ©lanie Joly, the heritage minister, wrote in an email. Even so, Professor Bird is among those now pushing to get a gray jay bill through Parliament somehow. And he expressed relief that another bird associated with Canada was never a real contender. â€œCanada goose? Over my dead body,â€ he said. â€œTheyâ€™re basically pooping machines, and theyâ€™re obnoxious. If we had picked that bird, we would be getting a lot more outrage than we have now. â€

title: Review: BeyoncÃ© Makes â€˜Lemonadeâ€™ Out of Marital Strife - The New York Times
author: Jon Pareles
text: Marital strife smolders, explodes and uneasily subsides on â€œLemonadeâ€ (Parkwood Entertainment) the album BeyoncÃ©   on Saturday night. â€œYou can taste the  â€™s all over your breathâ€ are the first words she sings in â€œPray You Catch Me,â€ and thatâ€™s just the beginning of an album that probes betrayal, jealousy, revenge and rage before dutifully willing itself toward reconciliation at the end. Many of the accusations are aimed specifically and recognizably at her husband, Shawn Carter, the rapper Jay Z. â€œTonight I regret the night I put that ring on,â€ she   in â€œSorry,â€ a twitchy, flippant song thatâ€™s by no means an apology. Itâ€™s a combative, unglossy track on an album full of them. â€œLemonadeâ€ is the kind of album that a star like BeyoncÃ© (as well as, lately, Rihanna) can release in the streaming era because sheâ€™s already guaranteed attention for her every utterance. The album is not beholden to radio formats or presold by a single fans are likely to explore the whole album, streaming every track and hearing how far afield  â€”   a brass band, stomping   ultraslow    â€”   BeyoncÃ© is willing to go. As she did with her 2013 album, â€œBeyoncÃ©,â€ she has also paired the music with   video that expands and deepens its impact. On their own, the songs can be taken as one starâ€™s personal, domestic dramas, waiting to be mined by the tabloids. But with the video, they testify to situations and emotions countless women endure. Itâ€™s not a divorce announcement the singer, songwriter and director is credited as BeyoncÃ© Knowles Carter. BeyoncÃ© released â€œLemonadeâ€ online at 10 p. m. on April 23, immediately after the HBO showing of the hourlong â€œvisual albumâ€ version. Itâ€™s a   music video that intersperses the songs, and broadens them, with compelling poetry from the   writer Warsan Shire, poems that often extend womenâ€™s physicality toward the archetypal. As BeyoncÃ© recites them, Ms. Shireâ€™s words radically reframe the songs, so they are no longer one womanâ€™s struggles but tribulations shared through generations of mothers and daughters. The video is filled with images of female solidarity and of family, Southern and African roots, women of all ages and roles and eras. Often, BeyoncÃ© is joined by   women in white clothes enacting shared work, gatherings of women or eerie communal rituals. BeyoncÃ©, in multiple hairstyles and fashions, is shown both alluring and unglamorous:   unhappy, sweaty, harshly lit. For the last few songs she often appears in a     dress remade with fabric patterns derived from African textiles, a rich twist. The album title comes from a family gathering thatâ€™s shown in the video and heard on a track: the 90th birthday of Hattie White, Jay Zâ€™s grandmother, who says, â€œI was served lemons but I made lemonade. â€ â€œLemonadeâ€ is not necessarily the album listeners might have expected after â€œFormation,â€ the song BeyoncÃ© performed at the Super Bowl with dancers in Black   outfits and in a video clip using images of New Orleans, of   in a plantation mansion and of BeyoncÃ© atop a police car, sinking under a flood. Itâ€™s the last song on â€œLemonade,â€ almost a postscript itâ€™s not in the extended video. One other song on â€œLemonadeâ€ mixes preaching and a prison song (both collected by John and Alan Lomax) a Kendrick Lamar rap and 1960s   psychedelia (sampling the collectorsâ€™ item Puerto Rican band Kaleidoscope) to call for â€œFreedomâ€: â€œI break chains all by  â€™t let my freedom rot in hell,â€ BeyoncÃ© vows. But most of â€œLemonadeâ€ arrives like a   to â€œJealousâ€ on the 2013 â€œBeyoncÃ©,â€ a song that moans, â€œI hate you for your lies. â€ â€œJealousâ€ is offset on â€œBeyoncÃ©â€ by songs about ecstatic lust, a topic largely absent on â€œLemonade. â€ In most of the new songs, BeyoncÃ© has been taken for granted or pushed aside. Itâ€™s a situation that, she finds, is both â€œa wicked way to treat the girl that loves youâ€ and also flabbergasting given that she is, after all, BeyoncÃ©. BeyoncÃ©!: â€œThe baddest woman in the game,â€ as she sings in â€œHold Up. â€  : She is. Her reactions swing from sorrow to rage to determined loyalty, and she reaches beyond the   of â€œBeyoncÃ©â€ to embrace new influences and collaborators: the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Father John Misty, Vampire Weekendâ€™s Ezra Koenig, Animal Collective and Led Zeppelin. â€œDonâ€™t Hurt Yourself,â€ a collaboration with Jack White, is a     that has BeyoncÃ© fighting back, declaring, â€œYou ainâ€™t trying hard   ainâ€™t loving hard enough,â€ working up to a scream. â€œPray You Catch Meâ€ is one of two collaborations with the British songwriter James Blake:   ballads of suspicion and longing. During â€œForward,â€ the other Blake collaboration, the video has its most moving sequence: family members stoically holding photographs of men who were killed by police. Itâ€™s followed by a scene of a New Orleans Mardi Gras Indian in full feathered and beaded costume, shaking a tambourine in posh dining rooms as if to exorcise them. Yet eventually, she makes peace with trying to hold on. â€œLove Drought,â€ with whispery vocals amid pillowy synthesizers, points out that â€œ10 times out of nine I know youâ€™re lying,â€ but strives to reconnect. â€œSandcastles,â€ a slow piano hymn that eventually gathers a choir, recalls a   fight but turns a double negative into a positive: â€œI know I promised that I couldnâ€™t stay,   promise donâ€™t work out that way. â€ By the time BeyoncÃ© reaches â€œAll Night,â€ a gospelly ballad roughened with electric guitar, she resolves to â€œGive you some time to prove I can trust you again. â€ Will it work out? No one knows. But in the meantime she sings wholeheartedly, encapsulates deep dilemmas in terse singalong lines and touches on ideas and emotions that so many people feel. She is a star whose world is vastly different from that of her listeners. But in matters of the heart, with their complications and paradoxes, BeyoncÃ© joins all of us.

title: Trump to Ask for Sharp Increases in Military Spending, Officials Say - The New York Times
author: Glenn Thrush, Kate Kelly and Maggie Haberman
text: WASHINGTON  â€”   President Trump will instruct federal agencies on Monday to assemble a budget for the coming fiscal year that includes sharp increases in Defense Department spending and drastic enough cuts to domestic agencies that he can keep his promise to leave Social Security and Medicare alone, according to four senior administration officials. The budget outline will be the first move in a campaign this week to reset the narrative of Mr. Trumpâ€™s   White House. A day before delivering a   address on Tuesday to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Trump will demand a budget with tens of billions of dollars in reductions to the Environmental Protection Agency and State Department, according to four senior administration officials with direct knowledge of the plan. Social safety net programs, aside from the big entitlement programs for retirees, would also be hit hard. Preliminary budget outlines are usually   administrative exercises, the first step in negotiations between the White House and federal agencies that usually shave the sharpest edges off the initial request. But this plan  â€”   a product of a collaboration between the Office of Management and Budget director, Mick Mulvaney the National Economic Council director, Gary Cohn and the White House chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon  â€”   is intended to make a big splash for a president eager to show that he is a man of action. Mr. Trumpâ€™s top advisers huddled in the White House this weekend to work on his Tuesday night   address. They focused on a single, often overlooked message amid the chaos of his first weeks in the White House: the assertion that the   candidate is now a president determined to keep audacious campaign promises on immigration, the economy and the budget, no matter how sloppy or disruptive it looks from the outside. â€œThey might not agree with everything you do, but people will respect you for doing what you said you were going to do,â€ said Jason Miller, a top communications strategist on the Trump campaign who remains close to the White House. â€œHeâ€™s doing something first, and thereâ€™s time for talk later,â€ Mr. Miller added. â€œThis is ultimately how heâ€™s going to get people who didnâ€™t vote, or people who didnâ€™t vote for him, into the fold. Inside the Beltway and with the media, thereâ€™s this focus on the palace intrigue. Out in the rest of the country, they are seeing a guy who is focused on jobs and the economy. â€ The budget plan, a numerical sketch that will probably be substantially altered by House and Senate Republicans  â€”   and vociferously opposed by congressional Democrats  â€”   will be Mr. Trumpâ€™s first big step into a legislative fray he has largely avoided during the first 40 days of his administration. Thus far, instead of legislating, he has focused on a succession of executive orders on immigration and deregulation written by Mr. Bannonâ€™s small West Wing team. Resistance from federal agencies could ease some of the deepest cuts in the initial plan before a final budget request is even sent to Congress. And Capitol Hill will have the last word. To meet Mr. Trumpâ€™s defense request, lawmakers in both parties would have to agree to raise or end statutory spending caps on defense and domestic programs that were imposed by the 2011 Budget Control Act. Mr. Trump is in a highly unusual position at a time when most presidents are finding their footing or confronting crisis. Despite his lament that he was handed â€œa messâ€ by President Barack Obama, Mr. Trump inherited a low unemployment rate, a lack of international crises requiring immediate attention and majorities in both houses of Congress. By contrast, when Mr. Obama took office, the country was losing 700, 000 jobs a month, and the global financial system was teetering on the edge of collapse. By the time he stepped up to the rostrum for his first joint congressional address on Feb. 24, 2009, he had already accrued an impressive string of accomplishments, including the passage of a massive stimulus bill through the   Congress, a gender   act, a childrenâ€™s health insurance law and executive actions that would ultimately help stabilize the financial and automotive sectors. With the prospect of a second Great Depression still high, Mr. Obama sought to rally the country, vowing, â€œWe will rebuild, we will recover, and the United States of America will emerge stronger than before. â€ Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, who was Mr. Obamaâ€™s first chief of staff, said in an interview Sunday night that Mr. Trump was trying to create a â€œsense of urgency, which most people arenâ€™t feeling right now, which was a reality to usâ€ in order to generate support for his unspecified economic agenda, including an infrastructure bill and a tax overhaul. â€œWhen it comes to all of these executive orders, the question is, does the public view what heâ€™s doing as action or motion?â€ Mr. Emanuel added. â€œIf you donâ€™t have real action, you create a sense of motion, so the public views it as progress. â€ In putting together their budget plans, White House officials are operating under the assumption that the rate of the United Statesâ€™ economic growth this year will be 2. 4 percent, according to one person who has been briefed on the matter. That is slightly ahead of current projections, but it is well below the 3 percent to 4 percent growth that Mr. Trump promised during the campaign. For next year, the operating assumption is only slightly higher, that person added, a sign that the budget process will not be too out of step with economic reality. The turmoil that has engulfed Mr. Trumpâ€™s West Wing is largely of his own devising  â€”   part of a calculated effort by Mr. Bannon to move boldly despite his teamâ€™s lack of experience, and despite the reluctance of many mainstream Republicans to work for a president whom many of them opposed in the partyâ€™s brutal primaries. â€œDuring his first month in office, President Trump has done exactly what he said he was going to do,â€ said Thomas Barrack Jr. a longtime friend of Mr. Trumpâ€™s who ran his inaugural committee. â€œNo president has worked harder or accomplished as much, even with tremendous political resistance forcing him to operate with a small team of outsiders possessing little government experience. â€ Lawmakers in both parties have complained that the presidentâ€™s big words are not yet matched by detailed policy prescriptions or a legislative affairs team capable of executing such undefined promises as repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act or rewriting the tax code. The budget outline will give Mr. Trump an opportunity to add some specifics to an agenda that has been defined by bellicose speech and the broadest possible policy strokes. Still, aides said Mr. Trump did not plan to change his style for Tuesdayâ€™s address. The speech, they said, is likely to have more in common with his clipped inaugural address  â€”   in which he declared, â€œThe time for empty talk is overâ€  â€”   than the   litanies of policy proposals favored by President Bill Clinton or the   invocations of national purpose preferred by President George W. Bush and Mr. Obama. Mr. Trumpâ€™s team, conscious of his recent reversals and a   approval rating that is among the lowest ever recorded, has emphasized his determination to break the partisan gridlock and inaction that has kept congressional approval ratings in the 15 to 30 percent range for years. At the start of an interview last week with Sean Hannity of Fox News at the Conservative Political Action Conference, Kellyanne Conway, the presidentâ€™s counselor, called him â€œPresident Action, President Impact, Donald J. Trump. â€ In a   of Sunday show interviews, Stephen Miller, Mr. Trumpâ€™s policy adviser, maintained that the president had accomplished more in his first month than most of his predecessors had in their entire administrations. In reality, most of Mr. Trumpâ€™s executive actions have had no more effect on actual policy than news releases. And his     order on the   Partnership trade deal came well after the agreement had been put on life support by labor protests and liberal opposition. One West Wing official, who requested anonymity to speak candidly about strategy, said the administration craved the   television images of Mr. Trump at   discussions with business executives every few days on one side, and the vehement protesters of his administration on the other. But his critics say such photo opportunities are all an act, a      rendition of â€œThe Apprenticeâ€ by an ineffective rookie president. â€œThis man is not a doer,â€ said Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, who will host a Monday â€œ â€ of Mr. Trumpâ€™s Tuesday speech. â€œOh, please. He has nothing to show for what heâ€™s been doing in office for 40 days. Itâ€™s all been squandered. â€
